ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Great TF, was helpful during class discussions. She is clearly knowledgeable of the course material.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  I did not interact with her in relation to this class, but she was certainly very knowledgeable during class sessions and provided appropriate guidance to other students.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti was an excellent TA - accessible, knowledgeable, and engaged in the class.

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti is great. She knows the field well and is very professional in her approach to TFing. She also is not afraid to relate to students on a peer-to-peer level and give advice beyond the bounds of the course.

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  I did not interact too much with Deepti, but the few times I did she was very accessible and helpful, and I have no doubt that if I needed more help she would have been very helpful.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Very responsive to emails and questions. Always giving positive and constructive feedback.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  She is an excellent TA, Helpful, Energetic, Organized, Knowledgeable.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 13. Professor Bailis makes himself accessible to students, and is invested in ensuring students understand the concepts for each topic. Question 15. Key class for students of energy studies, as well as those in the field of development.
4: This course met once a week for 3 hours, but I felt that the material covered was much less than what could have been covered with a twice-a-week 1.5 hour class.
Rob Bailis is an incredible professor who cares about his students and teaches well. I hope to take courses again with him next semester and hope he will stay.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The reading responses help to solidify the reading material, and the midterm and final papers allow for in-depth exploration. Sometimes the discussion sections don't add much to the learning experience, however it's good to talk about the topics.

I really appreciated learning about the social scientific framing of development and poverty at the beginning. Also, the topics and approaches of this course are not covered in other FES courses, so that was very valuable.
The readings were very interesting and gave a good base for each week's lecture.
The HOMER assignment was very hands-on and useful to learn a new program and some of the discussion sections were insightful.
Practicality for developing countries

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The course is taught in a single 3 hour session once a week. One hour each week is a student led discussion, which generally was not very useful.
The discussion section portion
The discussion aspect to the lecture sounds good in theory, but really needs to be better structured for it to be a true learning experience. Otherwise, it seems to be a waste of an hour every class.

Each class was structured as an hour-plus lecture, and an hour-plus discussion led by a student. While the lectures were very interesting and covered lots of material, the discussions often were too gimmicky and was more for fun than for serious learning or discussion. I feel Rob and Deepti could have provided more structure or guidance to the discussions to maximize the discussion and learning that went on.
Would have been great to get come feedback on the reading responses.
Maybe a little more interactvitiy during the lectures would have been good.
None

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Sometimes it felt that discussions became repetitive without much novel information that was additional to the lectures discussed. I'm unsure of how to make the discussion sections more fulfilling, as they largely depend on the students conducting them.
See the previous answer.
Yes. It was effective and interesting.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It broadened my understanding of energy issues, and informed me of places to look for future research/data collection.
This course satisfied a requirement for my industrial ecology and green design specialization.
This course opened my eyes to the complexity of energy issues and how energy sitsa t the nexus of many of today's devlelopment issues.
It covers the missing element of Energy in my entire selection as an important part of Environment

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interest in the subject matter
Personal interest
I took this course to satisfy a specialization requirement, to learn more about energy issues in developing countries, and to take a class with Rob before it was too late.
I am interested in working in developing countries and see energy issues as a major environmental challenge especially in the developing countries.
I am interested in developing countries and energy is a critical piece of development and capacity-building
It covers the missing element of Energy in my entire selection as an important part of Environment.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Just average
Yes. Comprehensive overview of energy issues in developing countries

Yes, I learned a lot about how the household and national dynamics in developing countries are very different from the issues faced here, and so addressing those issues require greater sensitivity and flexibility.

Definitely. I think the HOMER assignment was a lot of work but I learned a lot. One thing that would have been great would have been some more explanation on the software. It was slightly unclear what we were supposed to produce in the final write up and what kind of graphs/tables/information would be the most appropriate to portray the information. Maybe having one class to go over the homer software and working through some of the questions together would have been helpful, people could bring their laptops and go through the steps before diving into the full assignment.
yes
Yes. Perfect

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Disadvantages: Since the group size is relatively small, it is every easy for some members of a team to be free riders.
HOMER assignment was really useful in learning the complexities that are inherent in even the simplest of energy modeling situations.
Helped build relationships between myself and my peers; allowed for a more comprehensive mid-term project to be manageable in terms of time-load.
I really enjoyed doing the HOMER modelling assignment as a group, which gave a practical skill deliverable in an otherwise reading-based course.
Working with the group was great, just having people from different backgrounds and with different work experience was great for the HOMER assignment.
My group was amazing and I never would have been able to learn the new program on my own.
It was a technical assignment so group work helped in 360 view of the software homer

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Course will no longer be offered by Rob, unfortunately.

I'm not sure if this course will be offered at FES in the future. Despite some organizational issues with the course, I do feel a course like this focusing on developing countries is very important for FES to have, so I would recommend students to take more similar classes if they are offered.
Definitely take the course
